1326    /**
1327     * An iterator on values.
1328     * <p>
1329     * <P>We simply override the {@link ListIterator#next()}/{@link ListIterator#previous()} methods (and possibly their type-specific counterparts) so that they return values
1330     * instead of entries.
1331     */
1332    public final class ValueIterator extends MapIterator implements ListIterator<Integer>, Serializable {
1333        private static final long serialVersionUID = 0L;
1334
1335        public Integer previous() {
1336            return (index < 0) ? -1 : --index;
1337        }
1338        public int previousInt() {
1339            return (index < 0) ? -1 : --index;
1340        }
1341        public void set(Integer v) {
1342            throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
1343        }
1344        public void add(Integer v) {
1345            throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
1346        }
1347        public ValueIterator() {}
1348        public Integer next() {
1349            return (index >= order.size - 1) ? -1 : ++index;
1350        }
1351        public int nextInt() {
1352            return (index >= order.size - 1) ? -1 : ++index;
1353        }
1354        public void remove() { super.remove(); }
1355    }
1356    public final class ValueCollection extends AbstractCollection<Integer> implements Serializable
1357    {
1358        private static final long serialVersionUID = 0L;
1359        public ValueIterator iterator() {
1360            return new ValueIterator();
1361        }
1362        public int size() {
1363            return size;
1364        }
1365        public boolean contains(Object v) {
1366            return containsValue(v);
1367        }
1368        public void clear() {
1369            MultiArrangement.this.clear();
1370        }
1371    }
1372    public ArrayList<Integer> values() {
1373        ArrayList<Integer> v = new ArrayList<>(order.size);
1374        for (int i = 0; i < order.size; i++) {
1375            v.add(i);
1376        }
1377        return v;
1378    }
1379
1380    public ArrayList<Integer> valuesAsList()
1381    {
1382        return values();
1383    }
1384
1385    public IntVLA valuesAsIntVLA()
1386    {
1387        return new IntVLA(ArrayTools.range(size));
1388    }
1389    public int[] valuesAsArray()
1390    {
1391        return ArrayTools.range(size);
1392    }
1393
1394    /**
1395     * Rehashes the map, making the table as small as possible.
1396     * <p>
1397     * <P>This method rehashes the table to the smallest size satisfying the load factor. It can be used when the set will not be changed anymore, so to optimize access speed and size.
1398     * <p>
1399     * <P>If the table size is already the minimum possible, this method does nothing.
1400     *
1401     * @return true if there was enough memory to trim the map.
1402     * @see #trim(int)
1403     */
1404    public boolean trim() {
1405        final int l = arraySize(size, f);
1406        if (l >= n || size > maxFill(l, f)) return true;
1407        try {
1408            rehash(l);
1409        } catch (Exception cantDoIt) {
1410            return false;
1411        }
1412        return true;
1413    }
1414
1415    /**
1416     * Rehashes this map if the table is too large.
1417     * <p>
1418     * <P>Let <var>N</var> be the smallest table size that can hold <code>max(n,{@link #size()})</code> entries, still satisfying the load factor. If the current table size is smaller than or equal to
1419     * <var>N</var>, this method does nothing. Otherwise, it rehashes this map in a table of size <var>N</var>.
1420     * <p>
1421     * <P>This method is useful when reusing maps. {@linkplain #clear() Clearing a map} leaves the table size untouched. If you are reusing a map many times, you can call this method with a typical
1422     * size to avoid keeping around a very large table just because of a few large transient maps.
1423     *
1424     * @param n the threshold for the trimming.
1425     * @return true if there was enough memory to trim the map.
1426     * @see #trim()
1427     */
1428    public boolean trim(final int n) {
1429        final int l = HashCommon.nextPowerOfTwo((int) Math.ceil(n / f));
1430        if (l >= n || size > maxFill(l, f)) return true;
1431        try {
1432            rehash(l);
1433        } catch (Exception cantDoIt) {
1434            return false;
1435        }
1436        return true;
1437    }
1438
1439    /**
1440     * Rehashes the map.
1441     *
1442     * <P>
1443     * This method implements the basic rehashing strategy, and may be overriden
1444     * by subclasses implementing different rehashing strategies (e.g.,
1445     * disk-based rehashing). However, you should not override this method
1446     * unless you understand the internal workings of this class.
1447     *
1448     * @param newN
1449     *            the new size
1450     */
1451
1452    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1453    protected void rehash(final int newN) {
1454        final K[] key = this.key;
1455        final IntVLA[] value = this.value;
1456        final int mask = newN - 1; // Note that this is used by the hashing macro
1457        final K[] newKey = (K[]) new Object[newN + 1];
1458        K k;
1459        final IntVLA[] newValue = new IntVLA[newN + 1];
1460        int i, pos, sz = order.size, originalFirst = first, originalLast = last;
1461        for (int q = 0; q < sz; q++) {
1462            i = order.get(q);
1463            if ((k = key[i]) == null)
1464                pos = newN;
1465            else {
1466                pos = (hasher.hash(k)) & mask;
1467                while (!(newKey[pos] == null))
1468                    pos = (pos + 1) & mask;
1469            }
1470            newKey[pos] = k;
1471            newValue[pos] = value[i];
1472            order.set(q, pos);
1473            if(i == originalFirst)
1474                first = pos;
1475            if(i == originalLast)
1476                last = pos;
1477        }
1478        n = newN;
1479        this.mask = mask;
1480        maxFill = maxFill(n, f);
1481        this.key = newKey;
1482        this.value = newValue;
1483    }
1484    /**
1485     * Returns a deep copy of this map.
1486     *
1487     * <P>
1488     * This method performs a deep copy of this MultiArrangement; the data stored in the
1489     * map, however, is not cloned. Note that this makes a difference only for
1490     * object keys.
1491     *
1492     * @return a deep copy of this map.
1493     */
1494    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1495    @GwtIncompatible
1496    public MultiArrangement<K> clone() {
1497        MultiArrangement<K> c;
1498        try {
1499            c = (MultiArrangement<K>) super.clone();
1500            c.key = (K[]) new Object[n + 1];
1501            System.arraycopy(key, 0, c.key, 0, n + 1);
1502            c.value = new IntVLA[n + 1];
1503            System.arraycopy(value, 0, c.value, 0, n + 1);
1504            c.order = (IntVLA) order.clone();
1505            c.hasher = hasher;
1506            return c;
1507        } catch (Exception cantHappen) {
1508            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(cantHappen + (cantHappen.getMessage() != null ?
1509                    "; " + cantHappen.getMessage() : ""));
1510        }
1511    }
1512    /**
1513     * Returns a hash code for this map.
1514     *
1515     * This method overrides the generic method provided by the superclass.
1516     * Since <code>equals()</code> is not overriden, it is important that the
1517     * value returned by this method is the same value as the one returned by
1518     * the overriden method.
1519     *
1520     * @return a hash code for this map.
1521     */
1522    public int hashCode() {
1523        int h = 0;
1524        for (int j = realSize(), i = 0, t = 0; j-- != 0;) {
1525            while (key[i] == null)
1526                i++;
1527            if (this != key[i])
1528                t = hasher.hash(key[i]);
1529            t ^= value[i].hashHive();
1530            h += t;
1531            i++;
1532        }
1533        // Zero / null keys have hash zero.
1534        if (containsNullKey)
1535            h += value[n].hashHive();
1536        return h;
1537    }
1538    /**
1539     * Returns the maximum number of entries that can be filled before rehashing.
1540     *
1541     * @param n the size of the backing array.
1542     * @param f the load factor.
1543     * @return the maximum number of entries before rehashing.
1544     */
1545    public static int maxFill(final int n, final float f) {
1546        /* We must guarantee that there is always at least
1547                 * one free entry (even with pathological load factors). */
1548        return Math.min((int) Math.ceil(n * f), n - 1);
1549    }
1550
1551    /**
1552     * Returns the maximum number of entries that can be filled before rehashing.
1553     *
1554     * @param n the size of the backing array.
1555     * @param f the load factor.
1556     * @return the maximum number of entries before rehashing.
1557     */
1558    public static long maxFill(final long n, final float f) {
1559                /* We must guarantee that there is always at least
1560                 * one free entry (even with pathological load factors). */
1561        return Math.min((long) Math.ceil(n * f), n - 1);
1562    }
1563
1564    /**
1565     * Returns the least power of two smaller than or equal to 2<sup>30</sup> and larger than or equal to <code>Math.ceil( expected / f )</code>.
1566     *
1567     * @param expected the expected number of elements in a hash table.
1568     * @param f        the load factor.
1569     * @return the minimum possible size for a backing array.
1570     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if the necessary size is larger than 2<sup>30</sup>.
1571     */
1572    public static int arraySize(final int expected, final float f) {
1573        final long s = Math.max(2, HashCommon.nextPowerOfTwo((long) Math.ceil(expected / f)));
1574        if (s > (1 << 30))
1575            throw new IllegalArgumentException("Too large (" + expected + " expected elements with load factor " + f + ")");
1576        return (int) s;
1577    }
1578
1579    /**
1580     * Unwraps an iterator into an array starting at a given offset for a given number of elements.
1581     * <p>
1582     * <P>This method iterates over the given type-specific iterator and stores the elements returned, up to a maximum of <code>length</code>, in the given array starting at <code>offset</code>. The
1583     * number of actually unwrapped elements is returned (it may be less than <code>max</code> if the iterator emits less than <code>max</code> elements).
1584     *
1585     * @param i      a type-specific iterator.
1586     * @param array  an array to contain the output of the iterator.
1587     * @param offset the first element of the array to be returned.
1588     * @param max    the maximum number of elements to unwrap.
1589     * @return the number of elements unwrapped.
1590     */
1591    private int unwrap(final ValueIterator i, final Object[] array, int offset, final int max) {
1592        if (max < 0) throw new IllegalArgumentException("The maximum number of elements (" + max + ") is negative");
1593        if (offset < 0 || offset + max > array.length) throw new IllegalArgumentException();
1594        int j = max;
1595        while (j-- != 0 && i.hasNext())
1596            array[offset++] = i.next();
1597        return max - j - 1;
1598    }
1599
1600    /**
1601     * Unwraps an iterator into an array.
1602     * <p>
1603     * <P>This method iterates over the given type-specific iterator and stores the elements returned in the given array. The iteration will stop when the iterator has no more elements or when the end
1604     * of the array has been reached.
1605     *
1606     * @param i     a type-specific iterator.
1607     * @param array an array to contain the output of the iterator.
1608     * @return the number of elements unwrapped.
1609     */
1610    private int unwrap(final ValueIterator i, final Object[] array) {
1611        return unwrap(i, array, 0, array.length);
1612    }
1613
1614
1615    /** Unwraps an iterator into an array starting at a given offset for a given number of elements.
1616     *
1617     * <P>This method iterates over the given type-specific iterator and stores the elements returned, up to a maximum of <code>length</code>, in the given array starting at <code>offset</code>. The
1618     * number of actually unwrapped elements is returned (it may be less than <code>max</code> if the iterator emits less than <code>max</code> elements).
1619     *
1620     * @param i a type-specific iterator.
1621     * @param array an array to contain the output of the iterator.
1622     * @param offset the first element of the array to be returned.
1623     * @param max the maximum number of elements to unwrap.
1624     * @return the number of elements unwrapped. */
1625    private static <K> int objectUnwrap(final Iterator<? extends K> i, final K[] array, int offset, final int max ) {
1626        if ( max < 0 ) throw new IllegalArgumentException( "The maximum number of elements (" + max + ") is negative" );
1627        if ( offset < 0 || offset + max > array.length ) throw new IllegalArgumentException();
1628        int j = max;
1629        while ( j-- != 0 && i.hasNext() )
1630            array[ offset++ ] = i.next();
1631        return max - j - 1;
1632    }
1633
1634    /** Unwraps an iterator into an array.
1635     *
1636     * <P>This method iterates over the given type-specific iterator and stores the elements returned in the given array. The iteration will stop when the iterator has no more elements or when the end
1637     * of the array has been reached.
1638     *
1639     * @param i a type-specific iterator.
1640     * @param array an array to contain the output of the iterator.
1641     * @return the number of elements unwrapped. */
1642    private static <K> int objectUnwrap(final Iterator<? extends K> i, final K[] array) {
1643        return objectUnwrap(i, array, 0, array.length );
1644    }
1645
1646    @Override
1647    public String toString() {
1648        final StringBuilder s = new StringBuilder();
1649        int n = size(), i = 0;
1650        boolean first = true;
1651        s.append("Arrangement{");
1652        while (i < n) {
1653            if (first) first = false;
1654            else s.append(", ");
1655            s.append(keyAt(i)).append(':').append(i);
1656        }
1657        s.append("}");
1658        return s.toString();
1659    }
1660    @Override
1661    public boolean equals(Object o) {
1662        if (o == this)
1663            return true;
1664        if (!(o instanceof MultiArrangement))
1665            return false;
1666        MultiArrangement<?> m = (MultiArrangement<?>) o;
1667        if (m.size() != size())
1668            return false;
1669        if(!m.order.equals(order))
1670            return false;
1671        for (int i = 0; i < order.size; i++) {
1672            if(!keyAt(i).equals(m.keyAt(i))) return false;
1673        }
1674        return true;
1675    }
1676
1677
1678    /**
1679     * Gets the value at the given index in the iteration order in constant time (random-access).
1680     * @param idx the index in the iteration order of the value to fetch
1681     * @return the value at the index, if the index is valid, otherwise the default return value
1682     */
1683    public int getAt(final int idx) {
1684        if (idx < 0 || idx >= order.size)
1685            return defRetValue;
1686        return idx;
1687    }
1688    /**
1689     * Gets the key at the given index in the iteration order in constant time (random-access).
1690     * @param idx the index in the iteration order of the key to fetch
1691     * @return the key at the index, if the index is valid, otherwise null
1692     */
1693    public K keyAt(final int idx) {
1694        if (idx < 0 || idx >= order.size)
1695            return null;
1696        // The starting point.
1697        return key[order.get(idx)];
1698    }
1699
1700    /**
1701     * Removes the key and value at the given index in the iteration order in not-exactly constant time (though it still
1702     * should be efficient).
1703     * @param idx the index in the iteration order of the key and value to remove
1704     * @return the key removed, if there was anything removed, or null otherwise
1705     */
1706    public K removeAt(final int idx) {
1707
1708        if (idx < 0 || idx >= order.size)
1709            return null;
1710        int pos = order.get(idx);
1711        K k;
1712        if ((k = key[pos]) == null) {
1713            if (containsNullKey) {
1714                removeNullEntry();
1715            }
1716            return null;
1717        }
1718        removeEntry(pos);
1719        return k;
1720    }
1721
1722    /**
1723     * Equivalent to {@link #add(Object)}, except that it can place k at any point in the ordering (shifting up later
1724     * entries and changing their values to match their new positions in the ordering).
1725     * @param idx the position in the ordering to place k at; will not be used if negative or greater than the current size (it can be equal to the current size)
1726     * @param k the key to add into this MultiArrangement; its value will be idx
1727     * @return the previous position in the ordering that k had if already present, the previous size of the MultiArrangement if k was just added now, or -1 if idx is invalid
1728     */
1729    public int addAt(final int idx, final K k) {
1730        if(idx < 0 || idx > order.size)
1731            return -1;
1732        final int pos = insertAt(k, idx);
1733        if (pos < 0) return defRetValue;
1734        final IntVLA oldValue = value[pos];
1735        oldValue.add(idx);
1736        fixValues();
1737        return idx;
1738    }
1739
1740    /**
1741     * Gets a random key from this MultiArrangement in constant time, using the given IRNG to generate a random number.
1742     * @param rng used to generate a random index for a key
1743     * @return a random key from this MultiArrangement, or null if this is empty
1744     */
1745    public K randomKey(IRNG rng)
1746    {
1747        if(rng == null)
1748            return null;
1749        return keyAt(rng.nextInt(order.size));
1750    }
1751
1752    /**
1753     * Randomly alters the iteration order for this MultiArrangement using the given IRNG to shuffle.
1754     * @param rng used to generate a random ordering
1755     * @return this for chaining
1756     */
1757    public MultiArrangement<K> shuffle(IRNG rng)
1758    {
1759        if(order.size < 2)
1760            return this;
1761        order.shuffle(rng);
1762        first = order.get(0);
1763        last = order.peek();
1764        fixValues();
1765        return this;
1766    }
1767
1768    /**
1769     * Given an array or varargs of replacement indices for this MultiArrangement's iteration order, reorders this so the
1770     * first item in the returned version is the same as {@code getAt(ordering[0])} (with some care taken for negative
1771     * or too-large indices), the second item in the returned version is the same as {@code getAt(ordering[1])}, etc.
1772     * <br>
1773     * Negative indices are considered reversed distances from the end of ordering, so -1 refers to the same index as
1774     * {@code ordering[ordering.length - 1]}. If ordering is smaller than {@code size()}, only the indices up to the
1775     * length of ordering will be modified. If ordering is larger than {@code size()}, only as many indices will be
1776     * affected as {@code size()}, and reversed distances are measured from the end of this Map's entries instead of
1777     * the end of ordering. Duplicate values in ordering will produce duplicate values in the returned Map.
1778     * <br>
1779     * This method modifies this MultiArrangement in-place and also returns it for chaining.
1780     * @param ordering an array or varargs of int indices, where the nth item in ordering changes the nth item in this
1781     *                 Map to have the value currently in this Map at the index specified by the value in ordering
1782     * @return this for chaining, after modifying it in-place
1783     */
1784    public MultiArrangement<K> reorder(int... ordering)
1785    {
1786        if(ordering == null || ordering.length <= 0)
1787            return this;
1788        order.reorder(ordering);
1789        first = order.get(0);
1790        last = order.peek();
1791        fixValues();
1792        return this;
1793    }
1794    private boolean alterEntry(final int pos, final K replacement) {
1795        final IntVLA[] value = this.value;
1796        final IntVLA v = value[pos];
1797        final int op = order.indexOf(pos);
1798        final boolean isFirst = op == 0, isLast = op == order.size - 1;
1799        shiftKeysValues(pos);
1800
1801        int rep;
1802        if (replacement == null) {
1803            if (containsNullKey)
1804            {
1805                value[n].addAll(v);
1806                return true;
1807            }
1808            rep = n;
1809            containsNullKey = true;
1810        } else {
1811            K curr;
1812            final K[] key = this.key;
1813
1814            // The starting point.
1815            if (!((curr = key[rep = (hasher.hash(replacement)) & mask]) == null)) {
1816                if (hasher.areEqual(curr, replacement))
1817                {
1818                    value[rep].addAll(v);
1819                    return true;
1820                }
1821                while ((curr = key[rep = (rep + 1) & mask]) != null)
1822                {
1823                    if (hasher.areEqual(curr, replacement))
1824                    {
1825                        value[rep].addAll(v);
1826                        return true;
1827                    }
1828                }
1829            }
1830            key[rep] = replacement;
1831            value[rep] = v;
1832        }
1833        order.set(op, rep);
1834        if(isFirst)
1835            first = rep;
1836        if(isLast)
1837            last = rep;
1838        return false;
1839    }
1840    private boolean alterNullEntry(final K replacement) {
1841        containsNullKey = false;
1842        key[n] = null;
1843        final IntVLA[] value = this.value;
1844        final IntVLA v = value[n];
1845        value[n] = null;
1846
1847        int rep;
1848        if (replacement == null) {
1849            rep = n;
1850            containsNullKey = true;
1851        } else {
1852            K curr;
1853            final K[] key = this.key;
1854            // The starting point.
1855            if ((curr = key[rep = (hasher.hash(replacement)) & mask]) != null) {
1856                if (hasher.areEqual(curr, replacement))
1857                {
1858                    value[rep].addAll(v);
1859                    return true;
1860                }
1861                while ((curr = key[rep = (rep + 1) & mask]) != null)
1862                {
1863                    if (hasher.areEqual(curr, replacement))
1864                    {
1865                        value[rep].addAll(v);
1866                        return true;
1867                    }
1868                }
1869            }
1870            key[rep] = replacement;
1871            value[rep] = v;
1872        }
1873        fixOrder(n, rep);
1874        return false;
1875    }
1876
1877    /**
1878     * Swaps a key, original, for another key, replacement, while keeping replacement at the same point in the iteration
1879     * order as original and keeping it associated with the same value (which also keeps its iteration index).
1880     * @param original the key to find and swap out
1881     * @param replacement the key to replace original with
1882     * @return the value associated with original before, and replacement now
1883     */
1884    public boolean alter(final K original, final K replacement) {
1885        if (original == null) {
1886            if (containsNullKey) {
1887                return alterNullEntry(replacement);
1888            }
1889            else
1890                return add(replacement) >= 0;
1891        }
1892        else if(hasher.areEqual(original, replacement))
1893            return false;
1894        K curr;
1895        final K[] key = this.key;
1896        int pos;
1897        // The starting point.
1898        if ((curr = key[pos = (hasher.hash(original)) & mask]) == null)
1899            return add(replacement) >= 0;
1900        if (hasher.areEqual(original, curr))
1901            return alterEntry(pos, replacement);
1902        while (true) {
1903            if ((curr = key[pos = (pos + 1) & mask]) == null)
1904                return add(replacement) >= 0;
1905            if (hasher.areEqual(original, curr))
1906                return alterEntry(pos, replacement);
1907        }
1908    }
1909
1910    public int[] getArray(K[] keys)
1911    {
1912        if(keys == null)
1913            return new int[0];
1914        int len = keys.length;
1915        IntVLA container = new IntVLA(len);
1916        for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
1917            append(container, keys[i]);
1918        }
1919        return container.toArray();
1920    }
1921
1922    public int[] getArray(Collection<? extends K> keys)
1923    {
1924        if(keys == null)
1925            return new int[0];
1926        int len = keys.size(), i = 0;
1927        IntVLA container = new IntVLA(len);
1928        for(K k : keys)
1929        {
1930            append(container, k);
1931        }
1932        return container.toArray();
1933    }
1934
1935    public IntVLA getMany(Iterable<? extends K> keys)
1936    {
1937        if(keys == null)
1938            return new IntVLA();
1939        IntVLA vals = new IntVLA();
1940        for(K k : keys)
1941        {
1942            append(vals, k);
1943        }
1944        return vals;
1945    }
1946
1947    public OrderedSet<K> keysAt(int... positions)
1948    {
1949        if(keys == null || positions == null || positions.length <= 0)
1950            return new OrderedSet<K>();
1951        OrderedSet<K> ks = new OrderedSet<>(positions.length);
1952        for(int i = 0; i < positions.length; i++)
1953        {
1954            ks.add(keyAt(positions[i]));
1955        }
1956        return ks;
1957    }
1958    public OrderedSet<K> keysAt(IntVLA positions)
1959    {
1960        if(keys == null || positions == null || positions.size <= 0)
1961            return new OrderedSet<K>();
1962        OrderedSet<K> ks = new OrderedSet<>(positions.size);
1963        for(int i = 0; i < positions.size; i++)
1964        {
1965            ks.add(keyAt(positions.get(i)));
1966        }
1967        return ks;
1968    }
1969
1970    /**
1971     * Produces a copy of this MultiArrangement, but only using up to the given amount of items to take. Does a shallow copy
1972     * of individual keys, so the references will be shared.
1973     * @param amount the number of items to copy from this MultiArrangement; will copy all items if greater than size
1974     * @return a new MultiArrangement with up to amount items copied from this into it.
1975     */
1976    public MultiArrangement<K> take(int amount)
1977    {
1978        amount = Math.min(order.size, Math.max(0, amount));
1979        MultiArrangement<K> nx = new MultiArrangement<>(amount, f);
1980        for (int i = 0; i < amount; i++) {
1981            nx.add(keyAt(i));
1982        }
1983        return nx;
1984    }
1985    protected int positionOf(final Object k) {
1986        if (k == null)
1987        {
1988            return (containsNullKey) ? n : -1;
1989        }
1990        K curr;
1991        final K[] key = this.key;
1992        int pos;
1993        // The starting point.
1994        if ((curr = key[pos = (hasher.hash(k)) & mask]) == null)
1995            return -1;
1996        if (hasher.areEqual(k, curr))
1997            return pos;
1998        // There's always an unused entry.
1999        while (true) {
2000            if ((curr = key[pos = pos + 1 & mask]) == null)
2001                return -1;
2002            if (hasher.areEqual(k, curr))
2003                return pos;
2004        }
2005    }
2006
2007    /**
2008     * Swaps the positions in the ordering for the given items, if they are both present. Returns true if the ordering
2009     * changed as a result of this call, or false if it stayed the same (which can be because left or right was not
2010     * present, or because left and right are the same reference (so swapping would do nothing)).
2011     * @param left an item that should be present in this OrderedSet
2012     * @param right an item that should be present in this OrderedSet
2013     * @return true if this OrderedSet changed in ordering as a result of this call, or false otherwise
2014     */
2015    public boolean swap(final K left, final K right)
2016    {
2017        if(left == right) return false;
2018        int posL = positionOf(left), posR = positionOf(right);
2019        IntVLA l = value[posL];
2020        if(l == null) return false;
2021        IntVLA r = value[posR];
2022        if(r == null) return false;
2023        value[posR] = l;
2024        value[posL] = r;
2025        for (int i = 0; i < l.size; i++) {
2026            order.set(l.get(i), posR);
2027        }
2028        for (int i = 0; i < r.size; i++) {
2029            order.set(r.get(i), posL);
2030        }
2031        return true;
2032    }
2033    /**
2034     * Swaps the given indices in the ordering, if they are both ints between 0 and size. Returns true if the ordering
2035     * changed as a result of this call, or false if it stayed the same (which can be because left or right referred to
2036     * an out-of-bounds index, or because left and right are equal (so swapping would do nothing)).
2037     * @param left an index of an item in this OrderedSet, at least 0 and less than {@link #size()}
2038     * @param right an index of an item in this OrderedSet, at least 0 and less than {@link #size()}
2039     * @return true if this OrderedSet changed in ordering as a result of this call, or false otherwise
2040     */
2041    public boolean swapIndices(final int left, final int right)
2042    {
2043        if(left < 0 || right < 0 || left >= order.size || right >= order.size || left == right) return false;
2044        int posL = order.get(left), posR = order.get(right);
2045        value[posL].set(value[posL].indexOf(left), right);
2046        value[posR].set(value[posR].indexOf(right), left);
2047        order.swap(left, right);
2048        return true;
2049    }
2050
2051}
